title: How to Bake Marble Brownies

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 325 degrees.
steps.description: 325 is the ideal temperature because it allows the brownies to cook perfectly in the inside. They will come out moist and delicious.

steps.headline: Mist an 8 by 8 inch pan with non-stick cooking spray.
steps.description: The cooking spray allows the brownies not to stick to the pan and ruin them. The recipe calls for an 8 by 8 pan to make the brownies the perfect height and density. If you want to make a larger portion, you can double the pan along with doubling the ingredients.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/a\/a7\/Coa-and-salt.jpeg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/a\/a7\/Coa-and-salt.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":505.74545454545455,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Place the sugar, butter, cocoa, and salt in a large microwaveable safe bowl.
steps.description: All the ingredients must be mixed at together so the batter becomes even. Everything should be mixed throughly.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/06\/Microwave-min.jpeg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/0\/06\/Microwave-min.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":303,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":501.15942028985506,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Microwave in one minute increments until butter is completely melted.
steps.description: Between the minutes, the butter should be beat and stirred to have no clumps. Clumps result in unevenly tasting brownies. The butter must be dispersed evenly to have perfect tasting brownies!

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/eb\/Eggs-eating.jpeg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/e\/eb\/Eggs-eating.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":505.74545454545455,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add the eggs, one at a time stirring each egg for thirty seconds.
steps.description: There is a total of five eggs so mixing each one into the batter and stirring for 30 seconds is crucial to get well beat eggs.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/ff\/Wholegian.jpeg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/f\/ff\/Wholegian.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Stir in the whole grain flour until it is fully mixed.
steps.description: This must be mixed with all the ingredients to achieve a thick consistency of brownie batter. White flour is okay as well but whole grain is healthier and richer in taste.

steps.headline: Slowly whisk in the vanilla to the brownie batter.
steps.description: Whisking slowly allows the vanilla to disperse within the mix evenly. Make sure the vanilla is evenly distributed throughout the batter so that every bite has a consistent flavor profile.

steps.headline: Beat the cream cheese in a large bowl until creamy.
steps.description: This can be done in any size bowl as long as the cream cheese is completely creamy and fluffy in texture. A large bowl is preferred to allow the stirring and beating process to be easier. Set aside the whipped cream cheese to drop into the brownie mix later.

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b8\/Cakekekaelq.jpeg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/b8\/Cakekekaelq.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":323,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":533.1343283582089,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add the brownie batter to the pan.
steps.description: You can use a rubber spatula to scrape any sticking batter into the baking pan. This is the fun step, where all the hard work comes together in preparation to bake the brownies!

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/3\/3b\/Arblee.jpeg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/3\/3b\/Arblee.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":305,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":503.9130434782609,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Drop tablespoons of the cream cheese mix over the brownie butter.
steps.description: This gives the marble effect on the brownies.

steps.headline: Swirl gently with a knife.
steps.description: The swirling is dependent on you. You can  make cool designs or just simply swirl. The brownies will look good and taste delicious either way!

steps.headline:
{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/db\/137846lg.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/d\/db\/137846lg.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use<\/a> (screenshot)
\n<\/p><\/div>"} Bake 35 to 40 minutes.
steps.description: You can use a toothpick to check if the brownies have cooked thoroughly. Undercooked brownies can be dangerous because of the raw eggs. Overcooked brownies can come out dry or burned. Make sure to watch the time and check in on your brownies every so often.

text:
Preheat the oven to 325 degrees. 325 is the ideal temperature because it allows the brownies to cook perfectly in the inside. They will come out moist and delicious. Mist an 8 by 8 inch pan with non-stick cooking spray. The cooking spray allows the brownies not to stick to the pan and ruin them. The recipe calls for an 8 by 8 pan to make the brownies the perfect height and density. If you want to make a larger portion, you can double the pan along with doubling the ingredients. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a7/Coa-and-salt.jpeg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/a/a7/Coa-and-salt.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":505.74545454545455,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use (screenshot)

"} Place the sugar, butter, cocoa, and salt in a large microwaveable safe bowl. All the ingredients must be mixed at together so the batter becomes even. Everything should be mixed throughly. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/06/Microwave-min.jpeg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/0/06/Microwave-min.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":303,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":501.15942028985506,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use (screenshot)

"} Microwave in one minute increments until butter is completely melted. Between the minutes, the butter should be beat and stirred to have no clumps. Clumps result in unevenly tasting brownies. The butter must be dispersed evenly to have perfect tasting brownies! {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/eb/Eggs-eating.jpeg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/eb/Eggs-eating.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":505.74545454545455,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use (screenshot)

"} Add the eggs, one at a time stirring each egg for thirty seconds. There is a total of five eggs so mixing each one into the batter and stirring for 30 seconds is crucial to get well beat eggs. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/ff/Wholegian.jpeg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/ff/Wholegian.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use (screenshot)

"} Stir in the whole grain flour until it is fully mixed. This must be mixed with all the ingredients to achieve a thick consistency of brownie batter. White flour is okay as well but whole grain is healthier and richer in taste. Slowly whisk in the vanilla to the brownie batter. Whisking slowly allows the vanilla to disperse within the mix evenly. Make sure the vanilla is evenly distributed throughout the batter so that every bite has a consistent flavor profile. Beat the cream cheese in a large bowl until creamy. This can be done in any size bowl as long as the cream cheese is completely creamy and fluffy in texture. A large bowl is preferred to allow the stirring and beating process to be easier. Set aside the whipped cream cheese to drop into the brownie mix later. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b8/Cakekekaelq.jpeg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b8/Cakekekaelq.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":323,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":533.1343283582089,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use (screenshot)

"} Add the brownie batter to the pan. You can use a rubber spatula to scrape any sticking batter into the baking pan. This is the fun step, where all the hard work comes together in preparation to bake the brownies! {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/3b/Arblee.jpeg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/3/3b/Arblee.jpeg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":305,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":503.9130434782609,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use (screenshot)

"} Drop tablespoons of the cream cheese mix over the brownie butter. This gives the marble effect on the brownies. Swirl gently with a knife. The swirling is dependent on you. You can make cool designs or just simply swirl. The brownies will look good and taste delicious either way! {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/db/137846lg.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/d/db/137846lg.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Fair Use (screenshot)

"} Bake 35 to 40 minutes. You can use a toothpick to check if the brownies have cooked thoroughly. Undercooked brownies can be dangerous because of the raw eggs. Overcooked brownies can come out dry or burned. Make sure to watch the time and check in on your brownies every so often.
